Summary My carrier has focused on technology transfer, introduction and development of new process and products, installation and Qualification of equipment and certification of new manufacturing site in semiconductor area. Seventeen years of experience working at Intel Corporation in Costa Rica. 
I worked in several technology, products, process and equipment development projects in Arizona USA, Germany and Malaysia. Some of them I led and for which the results became worldwide standard for the manufacturing process of microprocessors at Intel across all factories. I led and managed teams of multi-disciplinary (Mechanical, Industrial, Electronics, Quality Engineers and other areas like finance) and multi-cultural (From USA, Costa Rica, India, Malaysia, Germany, Philippines, China) professionals for new process and products transfer, equipment install and qualification, continuous improvement and process management and control.  
I also worked in a technology transfer project with the International Research Center of Canada and the chambers of Industry of a Central America during 1995-1997. Speaker on Behalf of the Organization of American States in technology transfer conferences to chambers of Industry in Trinidad&Tobago, Colombia, Ecuador and Costa Rica. Experience Technical Lead Intel May 1997  – Present (18 years 4 months) Costa Rica Currently working as a Technical leader across different modules in Assembly engineering area, in charge of continuous improvement projects; Installation and qualification of new equipment and new processes; Transfer of new technologies, platforms and products; Engineering development and up-skilling; New engineers interviewing and selection; manufacturing indicators improvement like Maintenance, Conversions and Machine Availability; Chip Attach (CAM) Assembly & Test Operations Transfer Manager Intel Corporation February 2010  –  February 2012  (2 years 1 month) Phoenix, Arizona Area Moved to Arizona in a two way temporary assignment for 2 years to work as Chip Attach Module transfer manager with Assembly and Test Operations, in charge of technology transfer between the Development site in Arizona for Assembly and Test technology and the seven factories around the world in charge of High volume manufacturing of Microprocessors. Main roles were: to create, maintain and publish schedules for the transfer of several new platforms and products; approval of process changes and responsible for the success of the new product, process and technology transfer to all seven sites and ensure new technologies and processes being developed were ready for High Volume manufacturing; Selection of early involvement engineers from the Manufacturing factories and Manage them while on assignment in Arizona. Project manager for Chipset Assembly and Manufacturing Transfer Line Readiness Intel Corporation January 2009  –  February 2010  (1 year 2 months) Costa Rica Project Manager for the LRT (Line Readiness Team) in Assembly area and the MRT (Manufacturing Readiness Team) for the new 17 chipset products being transfer from the closing factories in Malaysia and China. Responsible for the transfer, readiness and ramp to production of the new products across all modules and departments involved, from Engineering, Manufacturing, Finance, Materials Eng., Industrial Eng., Planning and Information Technologies. Chip Attach (CAM) Group Leader (GL) for both CPU and Chipset factories in CR Intel Corporation November 2006  –  January 2009  (2 years 3 months) Costa Rica Chip Attach New Technologies and Product Introduction Manager for both CPU and Chipset factories. On this role, I was responsible for directly managing CAM, Deflux, AOI, Pico Rework, Micro Rework, X-ray and APL operations for both factories. I supervise 21 Engineers and Indirectly (dotted line) 10 manufacturing supervisors in the area. On this position, I was focused on Engineering activities, New Product Introduction and technical issues; having excellent networking with other departments across CR site like NPI, Q&R, Yield, Integration and MFG, as well as other Assembly modules. Managed a annual Budget of $4 to 6 million. Chip Attach Module Sr Process Engineer Intel Corporation May 1999  –  January 2006  (6 years 9 months) Costa Rica 	Responsible for the overall performance of the area as measured by: Safety, Quality, Yield, output, and cost. Responsibilities include continuous improvement and sustaining Engineering, Install and Qualification activities for new machines and to supervise three Engineering Technicians. 
	Chair for the Assembly PIT (Productivity Improvement Team) during 1.5 years. As major accomplishments are $15.7M savings on capital equipment on 2002 and first half 2003 being the best PIT across CR site. 
	Project Coordinator for NGCAM development and implementation in CR during 2002. 
	To participate in several Development projects/assignment out of CR:  
-	Lead Eng in Arizona for development of 1264 Ph2 (Tulsa) . Led the Spray flux path finding team achieving “prove of concept” and process feasibility. Defined the basic process variables, flux materials and developed the basic process for spray flux on which all new platforms at Intel are being developed for CAM module manufacturing process across the world. Received the ATD Module Engineering award June 2006 and the ATTD Divisional Award Q3’2006. 
-	CR team leader for the No Flow Underfill (NUF) project. Assignment to Germany and ATD from July-Nov 2004. In charged of the Process and equipment qualification runs at Grohmann supplier, leading the VF team from Malaysia, Philippines and Costa Rica. Received the Quarter 4’ 2004 Assembly Capital Equipment Development/Assembly Operations Department award. 
-	Assignment to ATD for one year during 2000 for the development and qualification of X60 platform. Costa Rica site Sr. Chemical Engineer Intel Corporation November 1998  –  May 1999  (7 months) Costa Rica 	Work in facilities as the site chemical engineer, responsible for the overall performance of some of the systems that supply facilities to the CR1 and CR3 production factories. The specific systems are Nitrogen plant and Liquid Nitrogen distribution system, Ultra Pure Water (RODI), Hydrogen pad, CO2 storage and distribution system and Waste water treatment plant. The performance of the systems was measured by: Safety, Quality of the supply and cost. Responsibilities included continuous improvement and sustaining Engineering. Direct responsibility over 8 contractor technicians as sponsor. SECC MHS Install Qual Engineer Intel Corporation May 1997  –  November 1998  (1 year 7 months) Costa Rica Responsible for installing and Qualifying the Material Handling (MHS) equipment for Intel’s first factory in CR. As a brand new factory and green site, the SECC production lines in CR1 factory were measured by installation duration, stability on the production ramp, cost and safety parameters pre-established. It also included planning of the activities, continuous improvement, certification of the equipment and troubleshooting. Direct responsibility over 2 technicians Director Assistant Industrial Support Network Federation Of Chambers of Industry of Central America August 1995  –  May 1997  (1 year 10 months) Costa Rica This network was a international cooperation program supported by the government of Canada through the International Development and Research Center of Canada (IDRC). The main responsibilities were the coordination of the program, elaboration of budget and to bring support to the industrial sector of Central America on the modernization and introduction of new technologies by strategic alliances and technology transfer with partners in Canada. Also give technical advice on specific problem solving on the manufacturing process.  
Among other achievements are: Speaker in conferences sponsored by the Organization of American States (OAS) in Ecuador, Trinidad & Tobago and Costa Rica on the technology transfer and Industrial support.
